loans.name: Minda

texts.en: Minda T. is from the village of Macapari, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Minda is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Minda runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Minda has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Minda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Minda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Minda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rhenos

texts.en:
Rhenos is 36 years old and married with two children who are in school. He runs a school and a retail shop to earn a living. He has been running his school for three years now and he has a good turnover due to his good customer care skills. He is married to a teacher by profession who, with her knowledge, has really supported him in running the school. He also operates a transport business to earn enough money to educate his children and support his family since the cost of living is high.  

Rhenos has been saving money with his group in Faulu Kenya called "Taifa tence" which guarantees loans for its members. His wish is to see disadvantaged children go through school and be professionals. He dreams of accomplishing this dream and also giving the children quality education in the future. He has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to build another classroom.

loans.use: To build another classroom

loans.name: Mkaratusi Group

texts.en:
Josephina Fende, age 48, is married and has four children, ages 28, 24, 22 and 10 years.  She has had a shop for selling children clothes at Kariakoo for four years now.  From the business she has been able to earn a monthly profit of around $306.

This will be Josephina’s 5th motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used previous loans to increase her capital and she has paid back the loans successfully.  She hopes to obtain a loan to still increase on the stock of clothes.
	
Josephina will share this loan with her subgroup loan  of  Mkaratusi group which totals five members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.  

In the picture, Josephina is second from the left.

loans.use: To increase her stock of clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Uss' Group

texts.en:
Six people who live in Peam Sala village in the Kandal province make up this group loan. They will use the loan for different purposes to improve their business conditions in the future. 

Mrs. Uss C. is the group leader who has been selected by all the group members. She is a farmer who owns 0.36 hectares of land and cultivates rice to support her family. Since her farming is going well, she bought another small piece of land, but she did not have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Uss C. decided to ask for a loan to pay for the small piece of land that she bought. She is a widow who lives with another household member.

loans.use: To buy small a piece of land

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma C. is from the village of Macapari, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Norma is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Norma runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Norma has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Norma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Norma is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the third loan taken out by Norma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 40-year-old, hardworking lady. She sells clothes and shoes in her hometown to earn a living. She has been in the business for 10 years now.  She says that she has a high turnover since she has a good customer base because of her good customer-care skills.  

She has joined a group in Faulu Kenya called Tushikane P., which enables the members to access loans guaranteed by the group. She hopes to grow her business and improve her living standards now that she can access loans. This is her first loan.  

Her wish is to see her children go through college and be professionals. Her customers have different tastes of fashion and designs and she is not able to meet their demands due to her limited capital. She has therefore requested a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner, to add stock of clothes and shoes.

In the photo, she is the one looking up with a shoe in her hand; the other people are her customers.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes and shoes for sale

loans.name: Thy's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people who live in Peam Sala village in the Kandal province. They will use the loan for different purposes in order to improve their business conditions in the current year. 

Mrs. Thy Y. is the group leader who has been selected by these members. She is a farmer who owns 0.85-hectare of land and cultivate rices to support her family. In her rice field, she has a problem because it is time to cultivate, but she did not have enough money to support it. Thus, Mrs. Thy Y. decided to apply for a loan to farm in this current year. 

Her husband, Mr. Srey Sreng, helps taxi drivers find some customers. She has three children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory while the other is six months old.

loans.use: For her farm

loans.name: Roquesa

texts.en:
Roquesa A., age 48, owns and operates a business venture selling seafood products, primarily fish and shrimp, in the local community. Roquesa has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities. She is from the village of Dampil, Iagonglong, Misamis Oriental. She and her husband have five school-aged children. 

In 2004, Roquesa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Roquesa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. Roquesa is requesting another loan of the same amount, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her seventh loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To obtain additional seafood products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
Maribeth T. sells seafood products, particularly fish and shrimp, in the local community. Maribeth has been engaged in her business for over 40 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities. She is from the village of Dampil, Lagonglong, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old. She and her busband have seven adult-aged children.

In 2009, Maribeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Maribeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. Maribeth has decided to request a second loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To obtain additional seafood products to sell

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter operates a computer school and a cyber cafe where he provides Internet services to the public for a fee. He is 32 years old and unmarried. His business, which has been operational for two years, has really grown. This is because he has been saving his money with a group called Wangige Business Pioneers in Faulu, Kenya. Using his savings, he has been able to expand his business.  

He has requested a loan of Kes. 40,000 to purchase computers and printers and to expand the business premises. He hopes to start offering web design lessons and secure contracts to train at other schools. 

In ten years, he hopes to operate a fully established computer college.

loans.use: purchase computers and printers and to expand the business premises

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Lay Seang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of nine people, all of whom all live in Peam Sala village in Kandal province. They will use their loans for different business purposes. The members have elected Mrs. Lay S. to be their village bank president. 

Mrs. Lay S. is a fish vendor who sells the fish that her husband, Mr. Soth Yeun, catches in the lake and the river near their house. She presently faces a problem due to the fact that their fishing supplies are too old to use, but they do not have enough money to buy new ones. She has decided to ask for a loan to buy fishing supplies, and she plans to use the rest of the loan to install sewers for use in her home. 

She is the mother of seven children. One is a laborer, five are attending the local public school, and the youngest is three years old.

loans.use: To buy fishing supplies

loans.name: Kizota Group

texts.en:
Eva NgA., age 35, is married with three children, age 19, 7 and 9 years.  She has a general store business which she started in 2008. She works from 7am to 9pm daily and she is able to make monthly profits of about $437.

This will be Eva’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She needs the loan to increase her working capital.

Eva will share this loan with her loan group "Kizota Group" which totals 22 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Eva is just behind the green post in a blue blouse with white binding.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Argie

texts.en:
Argie L. sells seafood products, particularly fish and shrimp, in the local community. She also runs a mini-store where she sells canned goods. Argie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from these activities. She is 32 years old and is from the village of Macapari, Damulog Bukidnon. She and her husband have three school-aged children. 

In 2009, Argie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Argie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to  purchase additional inventory and obtain working capital. Argie is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her third from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her seafood-selling business

loans.name: Daryl Joy

texts.en:
Daryl Joy M. is happy taking care of her family, especially her four children whose age range is from 3 to 12 years old. Despite poverty, the love and support she gets from her husband is the bond that keeps her holding on to life and making it worth living. Her dream of graduating her children from college is her reason for putting up her own small “sari-sari” (variety) store business using a loan she received through ASHI. Proceeds of this business will be her financial source for achieving her dream. 

Daryl Joy hopes that someday her small “sari-sari” will grow into a huge grocery store that can bring convenience to people in their village. To be able to reach this vision, Daryl Joy is requesting a larger loan through ASHI (14,000 PHP). Her husband and the entire family is excited for Daryl Joy’s business endeavor.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her store.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria is widowed with children. She resides in and owns a house on Lubaga road, one of the city suburbs.  She takes care of additional family members.  Maria has multiple jobs like selling airtime, printing and typing work, a mini-restaurant and selling raw food. Maria works seven days a week and doesn’t rent her business premise because she works from her own house. The family has access to electricity and piped water. She wants to use this loan to buy airtime cards, another printer cartridge and foodstuffs for her mini-restaurant. She aspires to see her business grow big and to buy a photocopier.

loans.use: To buy airtime cards, a printer cartridge and foodstuffs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more articles to sell

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles, age 29, works in a motor garage where he repairs vehicles to earn a living. He started this business three years ago. He also runs a video shop to earn additional income. He uses part of his income to pay his two employees, and he also saves some of his money with a group called Tushirikiane Pamoja in Faulu, Kenya.  

Charles has been guaranteed a loan of Kes. 20,000 by his group members. He plans to use this loan to buy more tools for car repair. Charles hopes to become increasingly financially stable in the future.

loans.use: To buy car-repair tools for his business

loans.name: Cerina

texts.en: Cerina Z. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling a variety of different products in her community. She is 34 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Macapari, Damulog, Bukidnon. Cerina has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Cerina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Cerina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase products to sell. Cerina is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Mrs. Lang Chuong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 10 people who are villagers in Peam Sala village in the Kandal province. Mrs. Lang C. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members, who will use the loan for different purposes. 

She and her husband own a general store in the local village to earn some money to support their family. Since their business is going well, they want to expand it, but they do not have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Lang C. decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. Through this activity, they support six children, three of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell

loans.name: Loise

texts.en:
Loise N. M. is twenty-two years old and married. Her husband is a builder and they have one child whom they wish to educate to the university level. 

Her business is located near a main road in Kiganjo, Thika, and it is well known by the name "Mama joy shop". Loise owns this general store where she sells such items as sugar, flour, tea leaves, rice and others to the local people. She says the business is profitable and the only major challenge is debtors who delay payments, and she has to struggle to make them pay. 

Loise is taking a loan of 20,000 KES to restock her general store and grow it to a wholesale business. In future, she plans to buy a plot and build a house for her family. She is hardworking, honest and patient.

loans.use: To restock her store

loans.name: Farahiya

texts.en:
Farahiya is 30 years old and married with one child. She runs a boutique in Nairobi to earn a living. She has been in the business for ten years and has two employees. She is in a group of young members of Faulu Kenya who are determined and focused on improving their businesses. They meet on a weekly basis to save their money. The group guarantee loans for each other.  

She previously took out two loans of 90,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya, which she used to expand her business and pay school fees for her child and she successfully repaid.    Her greatest wish is to see her children through college and be professionals. She has requested a loan of kes 80,000 from Faulu Kenya to add stock of clothes for sale. She hopes to grow her business to a wholesale level and build her family a house in the future.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes for sale

loans.name: Albert

texts.en: Albert is a 31-year-old hardworking man. He runs a retail shop in his hometown where he sells household goods, plastics and utensils to earn a living. He has 10 years of experience and has a high turnover due to his good customer care skills. He talks well to his customers and gives credit to his best customers, which keeps them returning. His wife usually assists him in the business and their togetherness is what has brought them this far.  He saves part of his earnings with his group in Faulu Kenya called Extra Shinner and this enables him to access loans that the group guarantees. This is his first loan. He was previously selling chicken before he ventured into this business. His wish is to see his children go through school and be professionals. He has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy sugar, rice, cooking fat and utensils to sell.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, cooking fat and utensils to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Pamella

texts.en: Pamella isa single of two children and all her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a two roomed house where the family stays. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family,rent and school fees. Pamella owns a retail shop selling cosmetics and sells to all categories of people at both retail . Pamella is proud of her business because she can pay rent,school fees and feed her familty. She incurs transport costs to and from shopping and goes for shopping twice a month . She  . Pamella works seven days a week. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of cosmetics, like hair conditioners, weaves, braids and creams. Business challenges includes tarnsportation and evr increasing prices of cosmetics. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow big in order to buy a plot of land  to build a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics like hair conditioners, creams, weaves and barids

loans.name: Asler

texts.en:
Asler M. is from the village of Pocopoco, Damulog Bukidnon. He is 37 years old. Asler is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Asler owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling snack food and dairy products in the local community. Asler has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Asler joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Asler has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Asler is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Asler from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Norie

texts.en:
Norie E. is from the village of Omonay, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 44 years old. Norie is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Norie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Norie has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Norie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Norie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Norie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a 46-year-old married lady.  She practices farming to earn a living. She raises dairy cattle and grows vegetables, which are her major source of income.  She started the business in the year 2003. She says that she has many customers in her rural area who buy vegetables and milk directly from her farm and she distributes her products in her hometown.  She has joined a group in Faulu Kenya called Muninga Victory where she saves her money on a weekly basis. Salome is a hardworking lady who is really determined to improve her living conditions now that she can access loans. This is her first loan. She has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers.

The photo has been taken away from her farm in town.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva is married to a clerk at Mulago hospital and they have three children. She resides in and owns a house where the family stays. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Eva takes care of additional family members. She owns a stall selling all foodstuffs including fruits and vegetables. She also has other businesses like poultry farming, which she has been doing for the last three years. Her monthly expenses include food, school fees and transporting her foodstuffs from the market to her stall. She goes shopping for chicken feed every week and uses public transport to and from shopping. Her main customers are neighbors and those who pass by. Her major business challenges include rotting and damaged fruits and transportation. She joined MCDT because members can get timely loans. Eva aspires to expand her business further so that she can own different stalls in the neighboring areas. She also wants to acquire 800 chickens. She wants to use this loan to more boxes of tomatoes, oranges, onions, mangoes, pumpkins and eggplants.

loans.use: To buy oranges, onions, mangoes, pumpkins and eggplants

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is a 55-year-old hardworking lady. She has been selling clothes since the year 2003 to earn a living. She has many customers in her business due to her good customer care skills.  She has joined a group in Faulu Kenya called E. Shinner where she saves her money on a weekly basis. She has benefited a lot from the membership because she can access loans, which the group guarantees. She has also benefited from the discussions and training offered by Faulu Kenya. Joyce hopes to double her turnover and improve her living standards in 10 years time.  She has many customers who have different tastes in fashion and design and she is not able to meet their demands due to her limited capital. She has therefore requested a loan of Kes 40,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of clothes for sale.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Kassissan

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce en détail de tubercules d'ignames, elle exerce ce commerce depuis 2002, sa clientèle  est composée de personnes de tout âge. Elle fait face en ce moment en une baisse de son stock de marchandises, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat 20 tas de tubercules d'ignames. Elle  est mariée et mère de 4 enfants
texts.en:
This lady has an income-generating activity selling yam tubers. She has been carrying out this activity since 2002. Her customer base is made up of people of all ages. At present she is experiencing a decline in her stock of goods. She is thus requesting a loan for the purchase of 20 piles of yam tubers. She is married and mother to four children.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of yam tubers

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora W. is from the village of Membuli, Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Nora is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Nora owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Nora has been engaged in her business for over 24 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nora is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ea's Group

texts.en: This group loan has four people who are villagers living in Prey Phdau Cheung village in Takeo province. Mrs. Ea S. is the group leader. She was selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purposes. She is a weaver at her house. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Ea S. decided to apply for a loan to buy silk. Her husband, Mr. Yon Yoem, is a farmer who owns one hectare of land to cultivate rice to support his family.  She has five children. Three of the children are weavers and the others attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy silk

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles P. K. G. from Thika is thirty-seven years old. He sells assorted items like umbrellas, socks, handkerchiefs, bangles, necklaces and others to local women. He has been in this business for the last year and he says that the business is good and gives him enough income to take care of his expenses. At times, he says, the business performance goes down but he works very hard from early morning to late evening to ensure that his business is doing well. 

He is taking a loan of 20,000 KES to restock his business so as to keep his customers well supplied with the items they would want to buy from him. He plans to buy land, get a wife and work harder to get more finances to take care of his family. He is hardworking and hopes to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: To buy more umbrellas, socks, hair clips, etc. to sell

loans.name: Ana Fe

texts.en:
Ana Fe O. is from the village of Omonay, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 46 years old. Ana Fe is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ana Fe owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling a variety of different products in the local community. Ana Fe has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ana Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ana Fe is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ana Fe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.
