*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sandamali

texts.en:
Sandamali is a 41-year-old married woman living in Kekanadura, part of the Matara district of Sri Lanka.  She has four children: three sons and one daughter. Her husband works as a fisherman.  Her sons are working and her daughter is a student.

Sandamali has managed a business selling clothes to local customers for three years.  She has requested a 50,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help her business and purchase dresses.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy dresses to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is widowed with eight children and all her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a house where the family stays.  Margaret owns a poultry farm at her home, a business that she is proud of because she manages to pay school fees for her children. Besides this poultry business, she also gets some income from rental houses. Her major customers are shopkeepers and families who stay near her home. Margaret's business challenges include transportation of chicken feed and thieves. She uses public transport to and from shopping. She wants to use this loan to buy chicken feed and 200 chicks. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Margaret aspires to see her business grow big and own 2,000 chickens. She joined MCDT because she wanted to generate capital for her poultry farm.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed and 200 chicks

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is a 31-year-old hardworking lady. She sells movies, music tapes and DVDs in her shop to earn a living.  She was previously practicing farming before she ventured into this business.  Rebecca says that her passion for music is what drove her to this business, not the fact that the field is very profitable.  She supports both local and International music and she ensures that she sells only the original movies, music tapes and DVDs.   She is focused and determined to improve her living conditions and so she has joined a group in Faulu Kenya called Uwezo where she saves part of her profits. Being a member of the group, she has benefited in borrowing loans, which the group guarantees and from the training that Faulu Kenya offers. She has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of movies, music tapes and DVDs for sale.

loans.use: To add to her stock of movies, music tapes, and DVDs for sale.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Analou

texts.en:
Analou D. is from the village of Macapari, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 20 years old. Analou is married and has two children, a toddler and a baby. To make a living, Analou owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for her business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Analou has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Phillipines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Analou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. 

Analou is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Analou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more underwear to sell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice W. M. is a hard-working 37-year old lady. To earn a living, she sells clothes in her hometown. She practiced farming before she ventured into this business in 1997.  She has many customers because of her experience and her good customer care skills.

Alice is a member of a group in Faulu Kenya called the "Kiambaa Shiners." The group meets on a weekly basis in order to save their money. Alice has benefited greatly from this group, which guarantees loans that she can access to improve her business. She hopes to grow her business into a wholesale operation so that she can improve her standard of living in the future. She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Faulu Kenya, which she will use to add to her stock of clothes for sale.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes for sale.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adolé

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée et mère d’un enfant, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits alimentaires.pour gagner plus de client, elle fait son commerce de façon ambulante.son commerce grandit tous les jours, afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus élevée, elle doit augmenter son stock, elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 4 sacs de sucre, 12 bidons d’huile et divers.
texts.en:
This lady is married and mother to one child. She has an income-generating activity selling food products. In order to gain more customers she carries out her activity on a door-to-door basis, and her business is growing day by day. In order to satisfy her ever increasing clientele she needs to increase her stock. She is thus requesting a loan from WAGES in order to buy four sacks of sugar, 12 containers of oil and other diverse products.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sacks of sugar, containers of oil and other diverse food products

loans.name: Mrs. Phin Yeum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In the village of Tramug Chrum in Takeo province, there are seven people who are requesting a village bank loan together. The group members will each use their loans for different purposes. 

Mrs. Phin Yeum, who is a village bank president, has been selected by the members as their group leader.  She and her husband, Mr. Phach S., are farmers who own one hectare of land, which they use to cultivate rice to make a living and support their family.

Although they try to work hard, they do not earn much income. Mr. Phach S. and Mrs. Phin Yeum do not have children, but they live in a household with three other members. So in order to improve their family's living condition, Mrs. Phin Yeum decided to ask for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding and also some pig food.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn S. is from the village of Mialem, Jimenez. She is 32 years old. Jocelyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $81 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 3rd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Mend

texts.en:
Mend is 47 years old and lives with his wife and their two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a their own house. His children attend a secondary school.

In 1999, Mend started his animal and fishing equipment trading business. Since he started his business, his quality of life has been improving. His family loves all animals – he has had so many kinds of animals such as dogs, cats, ducks, rabbits, geese, turkeys and fish. His own land looks like zoo!

Mend purchases young animals at cheap prices and, when they are grown, he sells them for a profit. He has been planning to expand his business in the future. He is a very hard-working person and has great communication skills. And also, he has good knowledge about animals and he is always sharing this knowledge with people. He says, “I would like to provide my children with a good education and good morals. I have been planning to build a warehouse for my business in the future.”

In the summer time, Mend sells fishing equipment. He is requesting a 1,100,000 tugrug loan to purchase more fishing equipment to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more fishing equipment to sell

loans.name: Na's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Na S. is 58 years old and lives in Krasang village in Takeo province. She was selected by the thirteen members of her loan group to be the village bank president. The group members will each use their loans for different purposes.

Mrs. Na S. and her husband, Mr. Yory L., are farmers. They have two children. The eldest works as a laborer and the youngest is a student in the local school. To make a living, Mrs. Na S. and Mr. Yory L. own a plot of land and rent a piece of land which they use to cultivate rice. Mrs. Na S. decided to ask for a loan in order to hire farm laborers to help with her farming crop.

loans.use: To to hire farm laborers.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita W. is from the village of Dampil, Lag. Misamis Oriental. She is 62 years old. Rosita is married and has five grown children. To make a living, Rosita owns and operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, to the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over 32 years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2007, Rosita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Rosita has decided to lower her loan request to 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Rosita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Berna

texts.en: Berna is married with children and all her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a house where they stay with additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Berna owns a retail shop in Kitawuluzi selling all kinds of merchandise like sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, bread, milk, soda and other cold drinks.  She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like bags of sugar, boxes of soap, cartons of salt, cooking oil, crates of soda and crates of mineral water. Her monthly expenses includes utility bills, food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo L. is from the town of Poblacion, Damulog Bukidnon. He is 38 years old. Danilo is single. To make a living, Danilo owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for his business comes from selling cellphone accessories and music gadgets to the local community. Danilo has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Danilo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Danilo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. 

Danilo is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which he will use to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Danilo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the needs of relatives and other family members. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand his product offering.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene K. N. is forty-two years old. She is married and they have three children for whom they hope to provide quality education. They also want to teach them how to run a business so that they can learn about self-employment, especially with the current situation of job scarcity in Kenya. 

Her business is located near a garage in a busy area in Thika. She has a hotel in which she serves her customers rice, chapati, githeri (a mixture of maize and beans) and other types of local meals. Her business is known by the name Zebra Hotel, although it is actually a restaurant. Mostly she serves the mechanics working at the garage in the area. She says the business is very profitable but the major challenge she has is that the place does not have proper sanitation. 

She is using her 20,000 KES loan to buy foodstuffs to make meals for her customers, hence serving more people and therefore getting a better income. She is innovative, patient and hardworking.

loans.use: Flour, beans, rice.

loans.name: Thary's Group

texts.en:
In Chumrov village in Takeo province, there is a four-member group that formed in order to request a group loan. The group members will each use their loans for different purposes.

The group members selected Mrs. Thary P. to be their group leader. She is a widow with three children. Her two oldest children are enrolled in local public school. The youngest is three years old. 

Mrs. Thary P. is a farmer who owns a one-third hectare of land, which she uses to grow rice to support her family. On the side, she works as a weaver. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. But she does not have enough money, so she decided to request a loan to buy silk.

loans.use: To buy silk.

loans.name: Sroem's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sroem T. is 47 years old and lives in Krasang village in Takeo province. She is a widow who does not have any children. 

She was selected by the fourteen members of her loA. group to be a village bank president. The group members will each use their loans for different purposes -- to purchase supplies, equipment and other items.

Mrs. Sroem T. is a grocery seller who owns a general store. In order to expand her business, Mrs. Sroem T.  decided to ask for a loA. to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.use: To to purchase more groceries for resale.

loans.name: Josephin

texts.en:
Josephine M. is from the village of Tipan, Oroquieta City. She is 34 years old. Josephine is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $71 a month for these activities.

In 2005, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 9th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Chanda

texts.en: Mrs. Chanda S. was born in 1982. She lives in Ta Ou Khang Cheung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land which she uses to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Bros Sem (pictured on the left), is a cow middleman. Since her husband’s business is going well, she wants to expand it. Therefore, she decided to request a loan to buy two cows for resale. Mrs. Chanda S. supports two children: her older child is enrolled in a local public school, and her youngest is two years old.

loans.use: To buy two cows for resale.

loans.name: Kheang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Kheang K. is 42 years old and she lives in Krasang village in Takeo province. She is the leader of a group of eight people who are requesting a loan together. The group members, who selected Mrs. Kheang K. as their group leader, will each use their loans for different purposes.

Mrs. Kheang K. and her husband, Mr. Khy Krouch, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate rice in order to make a living. The couple has two children who both attend the local school. 

In addition to farming, Mrs. Kheang K. is a pig breeder and her husband is a rubber middleman. With both these businesses they can earn a small income to support their family. Mrs. Kheang K. is requesting a loan to bU. pig food to support her pig breeding.

loans.use: Requesting a loan to buy pig food.

loans.name: Narankhuu

texts.en:
Narankhuu is 42 years old, is married, and is the father of two daughters. He lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent called a ger. His two daughters, Enkhjargal and Altanshagai, attend a local secondary school. His wife works as a cleaner in a company.

From 2002 to 2008, Narankhuu operated with his wife a products-trading business at Narantuul market, the largest and most crowded market in the city. In 2008, he started his taxi business.

Narankhuu’s family is the most important thing for him and he says, “As a father, I would like to be financially available to provide a good education and other necessary expenses for my children until they grow up.”

Narankhuu requests a loan to buy a computer and a television for his daughters.

loans.use: To buy a computer and a television for his daughters

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie S. is from Poblacion, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 43 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Rosemarie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop. She has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Rosemarie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 26,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 19th loan taken out by Rosemarie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Tedo Koko

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de céréales, elle a plus de  15 ans d’expérience dans ce commerce ce qui lui a permis d’en acquérir une parfaite gestion, elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville d’anié, ainsi elle réalise de plus grande marge bénéficiaire sur ses ventes.  Elle veut gonfler son stock et sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour acheter 18 sacs de maïs et 3 sacs d’haricots. Elle est veuve avec 4 enfants à sa charge, c’est avec son revenu qu’elle subvient aux charges scolaires et diverses de ses enfants.
texts.en:
This lady has an income-generating activity selling cereals. She has more than 15 years experience in this business, which has allowed her to perfect her management of it. She gets her supplies inland in the town of Anié, so that she makes a higher profit margin on her sales. She wants to boost her stock and is thus requesting a first loan from WAGES, in order to buy 18 sacks of corn and three sacks of beans. She is a widow with four children in her care. With her income she can cover her children's schooling and other expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of corn and beans

loans.name: Prang's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Prang U. is 62 years old and the leader of a 4-member group seeking a group loan. The group is located in Prey Phdau Cheung village in Takeo province. With the loans, all of the members hope to increase their income in order to improve their family's standard of living. Mrs. Prang U. is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare field on which she cultivates rice. In addition to being a farmer, she is also a silk weaver, which earns her a small income to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. She is asking for a loan to buy more silks to increase her business activities. Mrs. Prang U. is a widow with three children. Two are silk weavers, and the third one stays at home and also supports the mother's business.

loans.use: To buy more silks

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian C. is from the village of Matuga Bajo Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 60 years old. Vivian is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Vivian owns and operates a transportation business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing transportation services to local community members. Vivian has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Vivian joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Vivian has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Vivian is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide transportation services. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Vivian from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide transportation services

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita L. is from the village of San Vicente Bajo, Oroquieta City. She is 62 years old. Lolita is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a fish vending business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Lolita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Everlita

texts.en:
Everlita C. is from the town of Poblacion, Damulog Bukidnon. She is 41 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Everlita owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells spices and vegetables. Everlita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Everlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Everlita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nim

texts.en:
Mrs. Nim N. lives in Daeum Rumdael village in Takeo province and was born in 1968. She is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land to grow rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Yan Yun, is a fisherman and as a side business owns a thrashing machine to earn some extra money to support the family. 

They have a problem because her husband’s thrashing machine is too old to use. Thus, Mrs. Nim N. decided to seek a loan to buy a new thrashing machine. 

She is the mother of three children all of whom are attending the local public school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a new thrashing machine

loans.name: Abla Azimédo

texts.fr: Cette dame est une femme au foyer avec 2 enfants, son mari est un comptable, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de jus, d’eau minérale pure water et des glaçons, avec les bénéfices qu’elle gagne elle contribue financière aux charges de sa famille. Le congélateur dont elle se sert pour exercer son commerce est en panne, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour s’acheter un nouveau congélateur.
texts.en:
This lady is a housewife with two children. Her husband is an accountant. She has an income-generating activity selling juice, pure mineral water and ice-cubes on a retail basis. With the profits she makes, she contributes financially to the household expenses. The freezer which she uses for her business has broken down, and she is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to buy a new one.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of  a freezer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more Garri (cassava flakes) to sell

loans.name: Yoeun's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people located in Phngeas village in Takeo province. Mrs. Lay S. is the group leader who has been selected by all the members. With the loans, all the members will use it to purchase supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Lay S. and her husband, Mr. Puthy Khaem, are farmers who own 1.50-hectare field to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from farming, Mr. Puthy Khaem is a photographer who can earn a small income to support his family. In order to support the farming crop, Mrs. Lay S. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer. Mrs. Lay S. is 44 years old and a mother of four children; three are attending the local school and the youngest one is two years old.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Renuka

texts.en:
Renuka is a hardworking, 32-year-old married woman living with her husband, one son, and two daughters in the town of Telijjawila. Pictured above with Renuka are her husband and son.

Renuka has managed a cinnamon business for twenty-five years, and is now hoping to expand into tea cultivation. She is doing this business with the help of her mother and sister.

Renuka has asked for a loan of 30,000 LKR from BRAC Sri Lanka to buy tea plants in order to expand beyond her cinnamon growing business.

Thank you for considering supporting this Sri Lankan loan.

loans.use: To buy tea plants

loans.name: Vin

texts.en: Mrs. Vin C., who lives in Krasang village in Takeo province, was born in 1954. She is a mother of three children – one is a seller in a local village, one is a farmer, and the other attends a local public school. She and her husband, Mr. Veng Sam (pictured right), are farmers who own a 1.3-hectare piece of land to cultivate rice to support their family. Since their farming business is going well they want to expand it, but they do not have enough land to cultivate. Therefore, Mrs. Vin C. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more land to cultivate rice.

loans.use: To buy more land to cultivate rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Sub

texts.en: Mr. Sub S. is 51 years old and a villager in Trapeang Leuk village, Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Ngaet S., are farmers who own a two-hectare field where they cultivate rice for a living. In this farming business, they face a problem because they do not have enough money to support the field. Therefore, Mr. Sub S. has decided to ask for a loan to purchase rice seed, fertilizer and pesticide, and to pay for a farming laborer. The couple has a child who is a farmer and fisherman.

loans.use: To purchase rice seed, fertilizer and pesticide, and to pay a farming laborer

loans.name: Roma

texts.en: Mrs. Roma S. is a 24-year-old married woman who lives in Prey Ta Pong village in Takeo province. She is a mother of two children, both of whom are too young to study or work. She and her husband, Mr. Sochea Ros (pictured left), are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. In addition to farming, Mr. Sochea Ros is a construction worker and Mrs. Roma S. is a tobacco middleman. With these businesses, the couple are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to support her tobacco business, Mrs. Roma S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more tobacco.

loans.use: To buy more tobacco

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en: Sylivia is married with four children and all her children go to school. The family resides in and rents a house where they stay with additional family members.  The family has access to electricity and piped water.  Sylivia owns a retail shop in Mengo Mackay selling all kinds of merchandise like sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, bread, milk, soda and other cold drinks.  Besides this retail shop business, she also owns a boda-boda (motorcycle) which brings in additional income for the family. Sylivia works seven days a week. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like bags of sugar, boxes of soap, cartons of salt, cooking oil and crates of soda and mineral water. Her monthly expenses includes utility bills, food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise like sugar, salt, soap, and cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more women's clothing to sell

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna O. is from the village of Butuay, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. Lorna is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Lorna owns and operates a junk-buying business venture, providing recycling services. The main source of income for the business comes from hauling junk and other waste material for local businesses and community members. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2006, Lorna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC, a Kiva partner. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Lorna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional plastics & other recyclables to sell

loans.name: Mom's Group

texts.en:
Nine people make up this village bank loan, and they all live in Prey Mien village in Takeo province. Mrs. Mom H. is the leader of the group loan and has been selected by the members. Each member of this group will use their loan for different purposes.
Mrs. Mom H. is 38 years old and a mother of two children who both attend the local school. She and her husband, Mr. Sovannarith Chak, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from farming, Mr. Sovannarith Chak is a wedding chef by which he earns a small income to support his family. With both these businesses, the couple still do not earn enough income to support their family. Therefore, Mrs. Mom H. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en: Robinah is a single mother of two children and both her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Robinah owns her house and her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Robinah sells second hand clothes at her home and at times sells door-to door, depending on the available clothes. Besides this clothing business, she also sells piped water to her neighbors. She has been in this business for a long time and wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. She sells to all categories of people at both retail and wholesale. Robinah works six days a week. Her major business challenges are the ever-increasing prices of second hand clothes and the rainy season.  Robinah aspires to see her business grow bigger so that she could earn enough profit to build rental houses in the available space. Robinah joined MCDT because she wanted to boost her business as MCDT was giving out timely loans.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothing

loans.name: Halimatu

texts.en:
Halimatu S. is a businesswoman who lives at Water Lane, Bo, and spends her time at her provisions shop at Tikonko Road, Bo. Halimatu is married to a diamond miner and they have three children who all attend primary school. She strives very hard to see that her children are well cared for in the absence of her husband, who stays in Kono.
Halimatu is highly dedicated to her business, and intends to increase her stock with the loan she wants to take. She will use the proceeds to educate her children and establish another shop for her sister.

loans.use: To buy provisions for her store

loans.name: Gabat

texts.en:
Gaba J. currently selling bags of charcoal at her store. She is requesting a loan to stock maize and beans to sell. Gaba is 30 years old and is married to a businessman. She has 3 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a car to transport bags of charcoal from the producers to her store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy stock of maize and beans to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama F. is a trader as well as a member of staff at First International Bank (FIB) in Bo. She lives at Fenton Road and has a shop at Labour Road. Her sister normally helps her at the shop when she is at work. Ama takes care of her mother and four sisters.
Ama has some entrepreneurial and financial skills in business. She intends to add more stock to her food shop from the loan she is seeking. In this way, she hopes to attract more customers as well as keeping the old ones. She also hopes to buy a commercial motorbike to increase her revenue base.

loans.use: To buy food products for her store

loans.name: Chanthea's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthea U. is the leader of this five-member group loan and has beE. selected by the group members, who all live in Rovieng village in Takeo province. The group members will all use their loans for different purposes.
Mrs. Chanthea U. is a 27-year-old married woman. She and her husband, Mr. Oun Orn, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare field to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from farming, they also sell rice and salt. In order to support the rice business, Mrs. Chanthea U. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to enlarge her business activities. The couple has two childrE.; one is a student in the local school while the youngest is three years old.

loans.use: To buy more rice

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine owns a store and sells cylinders at retail prices. She loves this business because of the opportunity to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business in the future. She is married with three children and she is 48 years old. Her children are excelling in school. Her husband also works to support their home. Josephine is requesting a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more cylinders to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Josephine is a LAPO client. Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more cylinders to sell

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
Marie C. is a businesswoman who sells on Mahei Boima Road by Shenge Junction Bo. She sells cotton and lace materials and has ten years' business experience. She is married with three children and they are all in school. She assists her husband greatly in taking care of the children, especially their schooling and medication.

Marie is seeking a loan in order to increase her stock to attract more customers and encourage old ones, so that she can get more sales and increase her revenue base. Marie hopes to use proceeds from the loan to continue to provide for her children.

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is widowed with children. She resides in and rents a one roomed house where the family stays. Her monthly expenses include rent, feeding the family and school fees. Harriet has a store where she sells charcoal at both retail and wholesale.  She incurs little transport costs to and from buying charcoal. Harriet works seven days a week. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. Her business challenges include debtors and the rainy season.  She aspires to see her business grow big and earn enough profits to build her own house.  She joined MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by getting more capital.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Sulaiman

texts.en: Sulaiman M. is an experienced businessman who has traded for about 15 years. He lives on Jumbu Street, Bo, and his shop is on Fenton Road. He sells various types of electrical equipment. Sulaiman is married with two children, both attending primary school. He usually sells on credit to staff of various organizations and collects his money at the end of every month. He is looking for a loan in order to buy more stock so that he can satisfy his customers' desires. Moreover, he intends to complete payment for a piece of land he already has a deposit on.

loans.use: To buy electrical goods

loans.name: Mura

texts.en:
Mura N. sells used clothes and sandals at the market. She is requesting a loan to buy shoes to sell. Mura is 30 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 2 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to continue to be able to send her children to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy shoes to sell

loans.name: Srina's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Srina C. is 30 years old. She is a widow with two children who are both too young to study or work. Mrs. Srina C. is the leader of group loan. She has been selected by 5-members, located in Rovieng village, in Takeo province. With the loans, they hope to increase income to improve their family living. Mrs. Srina C. is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land to cultivate rice for a living. For this farming, she decided to ask for a loan to hire farming laborers. Aside from farmer, she is a pig breeder and can earn a small income to support her family's cost of living.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to hire farming laborers.

loans.name: Najab

texts.en:
Najab S. sells bread and groundnut paste. She is requesting a loan to stock onions and tomatoes to sell.  Najab is 29 years old and is married to a farmer. She has 2 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Kea's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Kea S. is 50 years old and is the village bank president selected by eighteen people, located in Kandoeng Thum village, in Kandal province. The members of this village loan will use it to support their different purpose. Mrs. Kea S. and her husband, Mr. Phall Nop, are farmers who own a pL. of land to cultivate rice for a living. Aside from being farmers, they also breed pigs at their home. Mrs. Kea S. now is requesting for a loan to buy piglets for breeding. She will use the rest of the loan to support her farming crop. This couple has three children; two are seamstresses in the garment factory while the last one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding and to support her farming crop.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine S. is 42 years old and is married to a village head man in Tokeh: a rural community in Waterloo. She has 3 children: 2 sons who are in secondary school and one daughter who is in primary school.

 
She is raising 7 other children who are her nephews. They depend on her and they are all in secondary school. Josephine owns a fishing boat and has several young men who fish for her. She has been in this business for 10 years.


With this loan of 3 million Leones she intends to hire more fishermen and to buy more fishing nets. It is her hope to be a model in the fishing industry.

loans.use: to hire more fishermen and to buy more nets.

loans.name: Chanthoeurn's Group

texts.en: This group loan, which consists of fourteE. people is located in Kandoeng Thum village, in Kandal province. Mrs. Chanthoeurn E. is 49 years old and is the village bank president who has beE. selected by all the members. Each member of this village loan will use it to support their different purposes. Mrs. Chanthoeurn E. is a grocery seller who can earn a small income to support her family's costs of living. Since this business is going well she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more groceries to sell. Mrs. Chanthoeurn E. is a widow with four childrE.; two are seamstresses in the garment factory and one is a student and also supports her mother's business while the youngest one is 4 years old.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to purchase more groceries.

loans.name: Lakot

texts.en:
Lakot C. sells foodstuffs like rice, beans and bread in her restaurant. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and beans to cook and sell in the restaurant. Lakot is 43 years old and is widowed. She has 6 children who do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy more stock of rice and beans to cook and sell in her restaurant

loans.name: Davaasambuu

texts.en:
Davaasambuu G., 27, is married and the father of a 6-year-old son. He and his family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent) in a rented yard in Hovd province, Mongolia. Davaasambuu operates a clothing trading business at the local Ih Buyan market. He has been operating his business since September 2009. 


Davaasambuu used to study and work with his wife in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has since moved with his family to Hovd province. He has been working hard to provide a better life for his family. Davaasambuu is an open person. He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more clothing for his business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Koem Than's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Koem Than T. is a 32 year old married woman and she is a village bank president, selected by fifteen members, located in Kandoeng Thum village in Kandal province. The members of this village loan will use the loan to support their different purpose. Mrs. Koem Than T. is a grocery seller. Her husband, Mr. Prak Korb is a motorcycle taxi driver who owns an old motorbike to support his business. With both of these businesses they can earn a small income to support their family's cost of living. Mrs. Koem Than T. now is requesting for a loan to purchase a new motorbike to support her husband's business. This couple has a child who is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike.

loans.name: Abdumukhtor

texts.en: Abdumukhtor is married with two children. He is from Isfara in the southern part of Tajikistan. He sells foodstuffs in his grocery store. His merchandise is varied and of very good quality. He has been in this trade for almost 9 years. Abdumukhtor is very disciplined and responsible. He is thorough and his mind is very sharp – he can keep all his business details in his head. All these qualities have helped him to overcome many challenges that have come his way and allowed him to achieve success in business. Abdumukhtor has always sought to achieve economic freedom and independence. He is hoping this loan will help his venture to continue growing and to continue bringing him profit. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and marking the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please click here.

loans.use: to purchase more foodstuff to increase the product range

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Meet Isatu K., a 29 year-old woman from 33, Old Railway Line, Tengbeh Town. Isatu is married with 2 daughters. The eldest is in primary school, year 6, and the youngest is in nursery school, year 1. Her spouse works as an engineer for Afro international.


Isatu sells pharmaceuticals and has been in this business for 5 years. She joined LAPO, SL in 2008 and, as a member of a LAPO union, she has received 4 different loans. She expanded her business and bought more stock to sell.


Isatu is asking for a loan of 2,500,000 Leones to enable her open a new outlet in addition to the one she already has. It is her dream to have several outlets across Freetown.

loans.use: to open another pharmaceutical outlet

loans.name: Mahmud

texts.en:
Mahmud is a farmer who is not only devoted to his work but also to being the father of a family. He works hard raising cattle, which he takes out to graze in the early mornings. Without a doubt, it is not an easy task but the love for his family gives his work reason and meaning. Currently, Mahmud wants to improve his situation by increasing the number of his cattle which in the long run will provide better financial income. If you support him, he will be forever grateful.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand the business

loans.name: Tegshee

texts.en: Tegshee is 33 years old and lives with her 8-year-old son in Hovd province, Mongolia. Her son, Batlhagva, attends a local primary school. Tegshee operates a clothing trading business. In August 2009, she built her own shop in a yard which she owns.  Since October 2009, she has been successfully operating her business and has built a stable operation. She is a cool-headed person and focused on the future. She is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~2500 USD) loan to purchase a range of clothing at wholesale prices from China to resell in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase clothing to resell

loans.name: Nuri

texts.en:
Nuri is a woman with five children. Her husband left for Russia where he is seeking work. Since she was alone at home, she started her own cattle-breeding business. As Nuri had previous experience working on a farm, her business has gone well. Today, she has three cows. She also has enough hay and forage and has calculated that she has enough fodder for even more cattle. So she decided to take out a loan and purchase more cattle.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Alttsetseg

texts.en:
Alttsetseg is a widow and the mother of three children. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest daughter, aged 14, attends a local secondary school. Her two youngest daughters, aged 12 and seven, attend a local primary school. Alttsetseg operates a second-hand products trading business at a market called Yalalt. She has been operating her business since 1995, and has gained significant experience and steadily expanded her business.

Since Alttsetseg's husband passed away, she has been operating her business and taking care of her family on her own. She is a very hard-working person and is optimistic about the future. To save on transportation costs, she purchases her products with other traders. Alttsetseg purchases her products once or twice a month and spends 800,000 – 1,200,000 tugrugs (~570 – 860 USD) per purchase. As her business is the only source of income for her family, it is very important to her. She says, “As prices have increased, being in business requires more working capital. I will operate my business from one shipping container until my daughters have grown up.” She is requesting a 2,200,000 tugrug (~1570 USD) loan to purchase second-hand products for summer which she will sell from her shipping container.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes

loans.name: Rauf

texts.en:
Rauf M. is 44 years old and is married with three children. His goals are to grow in his personal life and in his business. His wish is to offer better service to his customers. His dream is that God will continue to provide him with more years of life so he can get ahead and fulfill his goals. He is a taxi driver and travels through the streets of Isfara, Tajikistan in search of customers. He has owned his business for 11 years. Currently Rauf’s car needs some repairs and he wants to borrow 1000 USD. Rauf thanks Kiva and all the lenders who make this help possible.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to completely repair his car

loans.name: Ikromjon

texts.en:
O. Ikromjon is 39 years old and is married with four children. He has a café where, together with his wife, he cooks and sells national meals and foodstuffs. He has had this business for three years. Ikromjon provides fresh foodstuffs and tasty meals in his café to ensure his clients have the opportunity to eat, have a rest and can purchase what they need. His business is stable which allows him to generate significant income and to ensure his family's standard of living.

Now, Ikromjon’s children are growing and the expenses for them are also increasing. Thus, Ikromjon wants to expand his business to earn more money so he can cover his children's expenses. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni to expand his café. By lending through Kiva, be an important part of the growth of Ikromjon’s business.
