The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON International's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To expand his business to earn more income

loans.name: Lutfullo

texts.en:
Lutfullo is a very hard-working and responsible entrepreneur. He is married, has two children and he and his family live in Isfara, Tajikistan. Lutfullo works in the central city market where he has been working for six years selling men’s clothing. His business is characterized by stability and consistent growth. Once a month, he travels to the neighboring city to purchase new goods. Lutfullo likes working for himself and his business has been the main source of income for his whole family.

Today, he would like to ask for a loan of 3000 USD to purchase new clothing to resell. We believe Lutfullo’s drive for success will help this young entrepreneur succeed and thrive in business. You can be an important part of his business's growth. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON International's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new clothing to resell

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Hawa M. is trader who has traded for over six years. She rents a shop where she sells drinking water and drinks. She started her business from funds she accessed from her younger brother. Being a very determined and hardworking woman, Hawa is direly in need of a loan that she will use to buy additional stock for her store. She hopes that, if successful in acquiring a loan, she will use the proceeds from the loan to better care for her children.

loans.use: To buy water and drinks.

loans.name: Tsetsenmaa

texts.en:
Tsetsenmaa E. is 30, married and the mother of three children. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Tsetsenmaa operates a raw materials trading business. She sells a variety of animal products including sheepskins. Tsetsenmaa has been operating her business since 1997 and has gained valuable experience. With her earnings, she has purchased a Korean car for her family.

Her husband, Erdenebaatar, is 37 years old and a driver for the Badamlah Dul company. Two of her children attend local secondary schools. Her youngest child attends a local kindergarten. Tsetsenmaa is a great businesswoman who has been working hard to provide a better life for her family. She is a very hard-working person with a good personality. Tsetsenmaa is requesting a 2,600,000 tugrug (~1860 USD) loan to increase her business's working capital.

loans.use: To increase her business's working capital

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou Koné  est un homme marié de 32 ans, monogame, il est père de sept  enfants et vit à Soromana dans une famille traditionnelle dans la sous-préfecture  de Fakola, préfecture de Kolondièba (troisième région administrative  de la république  Mali. 
Seydou fait le commerce de céréales dans lequel il est très sollicité.
Pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, il adhère au programme  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec  lequel il est à son premier  prêt.
Avec ce prêt, il compte acheter, 400  kilogrammes de grains d’arachide, 1000  kilogrammes de mil qu’il stockera pour revendre à une période où le cours sera plus élevé.
Il s’approvisionne sur le marché de Soromana les jours de foire et dans les villages environnants. Il revend à Bamako aux revendeurs et  aux consommateurs, au comptant.
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  40.000FCFA. Le bénéfice prendra en charge les frais scolaire, de santé,  de nourriture et le reste sera  réinvesti dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou Koné is a married man who is 32 years old, monogamous and father to seven children. He lives in a traditional family in Soromana, which lies in the sub-prefecture of Fakola in the prefecture of Kolondièba (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Seydou sells cereals and is very much sought after. In order to satisfy his customer base, which is growing markedly, he has joined Soro Yirwaso's loan program and is taking out his first loan. With this loan he is planning on buying 400kg of peanut grains and 1000 kg of millet, which he will stock to resell at a time when the price will be higher. He gets his supplies on the market in Soromana on fair days and in surrounding villages. He resells to retailers and consumers at Bamako, for cash. He envisages making an average motnhly profit of 40,000FCFA. The profit will cover school fees, as well as health and food expenses, and the rest will be reinvested in his business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en:
Winfred is a 56 year old single lady with four children. She lives in Lang'ata area, a Nairobi suburb where she manages her rental houses in the Donholm estate. The houses she rents out have been her source of income for the last three years. Her customers are mainly working-class people living in the Donholm estate.

Winfred has never borrowed from other financial institutions before but with this loan, she plans to pay her son's school fees. 

In the future, she hopes to ensure that her children get the best education.

loans.use: To pay her son's school fees

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a 41 year old single mother of four children. She lives in Dagoretti area within Nairobi. She normally sells beaded items like baskets, necklaces and handcrafted table decorations  at two different and famous markets (Maasai market and the Kenyatta market). She mainly sells to tourists and the Maasai natives in Kenya. She has done this for the past year. 

Agnes has applied for a loan which she plans to use to buy more beads to increase her stock in order to meet the market demands. She has never borrowed from other financial institutions before.

In the future, she hopes to be a supplier to other bead makers so she can increase her sales and improve her living standards.

loans.use: To increase her stock of beads to meet her sales demands

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 32 years old and married with three children. He owns a motorcycle which he uses for his transportation business to earn a living. He also runs a butchery to earn enough money to support his family and pay school fees for his children since the living costs are high.

John saves his money with his group in Faulu Kenya which enables him to access loans because the group guarantees his loans. He had previously taken out one loan from Faulu Kenya which he used to expand his business and which he successfully repaid.

John has requested a new loan of Kes 40,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy another motorcycle. He hopes to expand his business and build his family a house in the future.

loans.use: To buy a another motorcycle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a hardworking lady who sells tree and plant seedlings in Kiambu to earn a living. She has been in the business since 2004. She says that the business is very profitable because she prepares the seedlings herself and later on sells them. Before she ventured into this business, she was previously practicing farming where she grew cereals and vegetables which she sold in the market.

Mary saves her profits with her group in Faulu Kenya called Step Forward which enables her to access loans because the group guarantees them. She hopes to grow her business into a large-scale operation and improve her living standards in the future.

Mary has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy more seeds for her business.

loans.use: To add to her stock of flower and tree seeds

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elias

texts.en:
Elias, aged 27, is single and lives in Githurai area, a Nairobi suburb. It is an area of mixed businesses with a high population, most of whom are low-income earners.

Elias operates as a shoe shiner and has done this for the last seven years. His customers are mainly working-class people in the busy Githurai area. With this loan, he plans to set up a modest structure for his business costing KES 6,000 and buy a stock of shoe-related products to sell like shoe polish and other items which will cost him KES 14,000.

Elias has never borrowed from other financial institutions. In the future, he hopes to venture into the matatu (minibus) industry.

loans.use: To set up a presentable structure for his shoe shining business and start selling shoe-related products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 37 years old and married with two children who are in school. He runs a cereals store where he sells different kinds of cereals to earn a living. He has been in the business for six years and has one employee. David also rents his residential houses so as to earn enough money to support his family and pay school fees for his children.

David has been saving his money with his group in Faulu Kenya which enables him to access loans because the group guarantees them. He had previously taken out a loan of Kes 40,000 from Faulu Kenya which he used to expand his business and which he successfully repaid.

David hopes to grow his business into a wholesale operation and improve his living standards in the future. He has requested a loan of Kes 80,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to his stock of cereals, to buy a sieving machine and to pay for a license for his business.

loans.use: To add to his stock of cereals, to buy a sieving machine, and pay for a license for his business

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline, aged 34, is married and lives in the Ruaka area, a Nairobi suburb. It is an area of mixed businesses with a high population.

Evangeline operates a green grocery stall and has done this for the last six years. With this loan, she plans to buy crates of tomatoes, bales of cabbages and potatoes, and packets of onions to increase her sales turnover. Her customers are mainly consumers. She has never borrowed from other financial institutions.

In the future, Evangeline hopes to operate a large-scale greengrocery shop where she'll be able to supply other small-scale greengrocers to improve her living standard.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables to increase her sales turnover

loans.name: Lucy Gakuru

texts.en:
Lucy Gakuru, aged 40, is married with two children and lives in Nairobi. She operates a retail shop in Nairobi city center which she has done for the last four years. Her customers are mainly people who work in the city center.

With this loan, Lucy plans to add stock of items like sugar, tealeaves, flour, salt and other food stuffs. She has never borrowed from any other financial institution.

In the future, Lucy hopes to have a wholesale business and move to a better location.

loans.use: To add stock to her retail shop, she wants to buy things like tea leaves, sugar, flour, salt etc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more VCDs (video compact discs) to sell

loans.name: Lilian Thiaka

texts.en:
Lilian is a 34 year old single lady who lives in Githurai estate one of the Nairobi suburbs. Githurai is an urban area where most people are low-income earners. 

Lilian operates a primary school in Githurai and it has been active for the last five years. Her customers are mainly children from the Githurai area and its environs.

She has never borrowed from other financial institutions but with this loan, Lilian plans to use KES 10,000 to buy furniture for her school and use the balance to buy poultry feed for her poultry farm. 

In the future, Lilian hopes to expand her business and invest in real estate.

loans.use: To buy furniture for her school and poultry feed for her poultry farm

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca G. is currently in the business of selling dresses, trousers, bedsheets, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock shoes and sandals to sell. Rebecca is 40 years old and is married to a policeman. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a pharmacy. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy a stock of shoes and sandals to sell

loans.name: Timothy

texts.en:
Timothy is a 32 year old gentleman who is married with three children. He lives in the Kikuyu area in Nairobi which is an area of mixed businesses with a high population, most of whom are low-income earners.

Timothy operates a school which he has done for the last seven years. With this loan, he plans to pay examination fees for his students. His customers are mainly students from low-income-earning families who are within Kikuyu and its environs.

Timothy has never borrowed from other financial institutions before. In the future, he hopes to buy the premises that he currently rents.

loans.use: To pay examination fees for the students in his school

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 45 years old and married. His wife is a housewife and they have one child. 

He operates a taxi business in Nairobi to earn a living. He has been in the taxi business for 6 years and he describes his business environment as vibrant. He also operates a Matatu (public service minibus) business to earn extra income. In order to repair his vehicle, Joseph has requested a loan of 60,000 KES that is guaranteed by his group (Munyaka Karura). 

He thanks Faulu Kenya for empowering him and for financing his purchase of a public service vehicle. He hopes to have a fleet of vehicles and describes himself as outgoing and friendly.

loans.use: To repair his taxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Anne Njoki

texts.en:
Anne, aged 34, is married and has three children, She resides in Mwiki, a locality outside Nairobi town. She operates her business in Mwiki, a place with a majority of low income earners who buy embroidery for resale in other markets. She has done this for the last four years. 

With this loan, Anne plans to buy a stock of materials for embroidery to boost her work output. She has never borrowed from other financial institutions. In the future, she hopes to set up an embroidery school.

loans.use: To buy a stock of materials for embroidery

loans.name: Firida

texts.en:
Firida S. is currently in the business of selling weaving materials at a salon and is requesting a loan to stock perfumes to sell.  Firida is 33 years old and married. Her husband is a nurse. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start up a bookshop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock perfumes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards and phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Dramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Dramane Traoré  est un homme marié de 44ans polygame et père de dix  enfants qui vit à Kah dans une grande famille traditionnelle dans la  préfecture de Kolondièba   (troisième région  administrative de la république du  Mali).
Dramane fait l’achat stockage vente de céréales depuis plusieurs années maintenant. Il est très sollicité et apprécié.  
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, il décide d’adhérer au programme  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel il est à son premier  prêt individuel.
Avec ce prêt, il compte acheter, 400  kilogrammes de grains d’arachide, 1000  kilogrammes de mil qu’il stockera pour revendre à une période où le cours des céréales est plus élevé.
 Il s’approvisionne sur le marché de Soromana les jours de foire et dans les villages environnants auprès des paysans producteurs. Il revend ses produits à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et dans les grandes villes telles Bougouni, Sikasso etc, généralement aux revendeurs. 
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  40.000 FCFA qui servira à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Dramane Traoré is 44 years old. He lives in a polygamous family and is the father of ten children. He lives in a large traditional family in Kah, in the Kolondièba prefecture (the third administrative region of Mali). Dramane has been stocking and reselling cereals for a number of years. His business is well-known and popular. In order to satisfy the needs of his growing clientele, he has decided to join the credit program of Soro Yriwaso, and it would be his first individual loan. With this loan he plans to purchase 400 kg [882 lbs] of peanuts, and 1000 kg [2205] of millet, which he will stock up for reselling later, during the season of the year when cereal prices are highest. He purchases his stock at the Soromana market on market days and in the villages nearby, from farmers who grow cereals. He sells his cereals in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and in big cities such as Bougouni, Sikasso, etc., generally wholesale. He hopes to achieve a monthly income of 40,000 West African Francs, which will be used to support his family.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cereals [for resale]

loans.name: Joseph Ndung'u

texts.en: Joseph, age 22, is single and lives in the Ruaka area, a Nairobi suburb. It is an area of mixed businesses with a high population. Joseph is a mobile beautician. He has done this for the last two years. With this loan, he plans to buy more stock of beauty cosmetics. His customers are mainly ladies around Ruaka and its surroundings. He has never borrowed from other financial institutions. In the future, he hopes to open a beauty salon and a beauty college.

loans.use: To add stock of beauty cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 54-year-old Nairobi-based businessman. He repairs shoes and also sells secondhand shoes, a business he has been running for ten years. 

He also does mixed farming and sells farm products, including milk, to earn extra income. John offers his services to his neighbors and describes the business environment as dynamic. He is a member of the Rehema self-help group that has guaranteed his loan of 50,000 KES from Faulu Kenya. With the loan he will rent a shop for his business, add a stock of dye, buy tools for repairing shoes and add to his stock of shoes to sell. 

Since he joined Faulu, John says that he has been able to educate his children. He hopes to own a wholesale shoe business in the future. He describes himself as outgoing, vibrant and friendly.

loans.use: to buy tools for shoe repairs, rent a shop and buy dye

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sadana

texts.en:
Sadana J. is currently in the business of selling beer and local brew from her home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Sadana is 20 years old and is married to a policeman. She has one child and her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Cecelia Wairimu

texts.en: Cecelia, aged 34, is married with two children and lives in Kikuyu town where she operates a jewelry shop. She has done this for one year. With this loan, she plans to add to her stock of beauty products; i.e., earrings, bangles, perfumes and plastic carrier bags. Her customers are mainly women and market people buying carrier bags. She has never borrowed from other financial institutions. In the future, she hopes to expand in the same line of business.

loans.use: To add to her stock of jewelry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more salon materials to boost her business

loans.name: Amosi

texts.en:
Amosi is 27 years old and married with one child who goes to school. He runs a shop where he sells mobile phones to earn a living.  He was previously selling chloride exide batteries before he ventured into this business.  He is married to an employed lady and with their combined income they are able to live a decent life. He has many customers because of his good customer care skills. 

He saves his money with his group in Faulu Kenya (called Kikwetu) on a weekly basis, which enables him to access loans because the group guarantees.  He had previously taken out a loan of 20,000 KES from Faulu Kenya which he used to expand his business and which he successfully repaid. He has requested a loan of 50,000 KES from Faulu Kenya to add to his stock of mobile phones for sale. He hopes to double his income and improve his standard of living in the future.

loans.use: To add to his stock of mobile phones for sale.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia, aged 30, is married with two children and lives in Baba Dogo, a suburb of Nairobi. Lydia operates a salon in Baba Dogo where most clients are low income earners. She has done this for the last year and a half. With this loan, she plans to buy beauty products for use in the salon. Her customers are mainly Baba Dogo residents. She has never borrowed from other financial institutions. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy beauty products for use in her salon.

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden B. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and ice cream from home and is requesting a loan to stock dried fish to sell.  Kiden is 21 years old and is married to a teacher. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock dried fish to sell

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen, is forty-eight years old and married. He lives in Kangemi area, a Nairobi suburb. It is an area of mixed businesses with a high population; most of the residents are low-income earners. He owns rental houses and also does water supplies in the area. He has done this for the last five years. With this loan, he plans to finish constructing his rental houses. His customers for water supplies are Kangemi residents and offices in the area. He has never borrowed from other financial institutions. In the future, he hopes to diversify his business and build more rental houses.

loans.use: Stephen wants the loan to complete construction of rental houses

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is married to a businessman and they have five children together. All her children go to school and she takes care of additional family members (her sister's children). The family has access to electricity and piped water. Mariam owns her house. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Mariam has multiple jobs like a ladies salon, selling cosmetics and selling maize flour at home. She is proud of these businesses.  She has been in business for many years. Her main customers are women and she works six days a week. Mariam’s business challenges include transportation and the rainy season because she works from a muddy place. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of cosmetics, creams, and weaves and to boost her business of maize flour. She joined MCDT because they weren't asking for collateral before getting loans. Mariam aspires to see her business grow bigger and build her own rental shops.

loans.use: To buy creams, weaves, braids and maize flour

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Cette femme est âgée de 47 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d’attiégou à Lomé. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois. Elle a commencé ce commerce depuis 1995, elle a beaucoup d’expérience dans ce commerce. La pluie de ces derniers temps a détruit son stock de marchandises, elle souhaite se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 20 sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
This woman is 47 years old. She is married and mother of three children. She lives with her family in the Attiégou quarter of Lomé. To make a living, she works trading wood charcoal. She began this work in 1995 and has much experience with it. The last rains destroyed her stock of product, and she wishes to restock. She is asking for a WAGES loan to purchase 20 bags of wood coal.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of wood coal

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr:
Née le 26 Mai 1985 à Sikasso ville, Mademoiselle Awa S.  réside  chez son père dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après ses études section Secrétariat de Direction, cette demoiselle s’est initiée aux activités d’achat et de vente d’articles divers tels les  draps de lits, les pagnes wax,  les soutien gorges etc,  il y a environ sept ans. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée surtout de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de deux ans et ainsi elle sollicite un troisième prêt pour acheter, 15 paquets de drap, 5 douzaines de Soutien gorge et 10 pièces de pagnes wax en provenance de Dakar et de Bobo Dioulasso (respectivement au Sénégal et au Burkina Faso). 
Ses marchandises sont vendues de façon ambulante entre les structures professionnelles et à domicile, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born May 26, 1985 in Sikasso village, Ms. Awa S. lives with her father in a large, traditional family in Hamdallaye, one of the popular quarters of Sikasso village (third administrative region of the Mali Republic). After studying as a manager's secretary, she began buying and selling diverse articles like bed linens, waxed fabric, bras, etc., about seven years ago. She is often solicited by clients for the quality of her products. With the intention of better satisfying her growing clientele, Awa decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. She is asking for her third loan to purchase 15 bundles of sheets, five dozen bras, and ten pieces of waxed fabric in Dakar and Bobo Dioulasso (in Sénégal and Burkina Faso, respectively). Awa sells her merchandise door-to-door at businesses and in homes. Her clients are primarily women. She foresees making a monthly profit of 200,000 FCFA which will be used to increase her commercial funds, contribute to her family's expenses, pay the interest on the loan, and invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sheets, waxed fabric, and bras

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuff to sell

loans.name: Ghassan

texts.en:
Ghassan is a fifty-five-year-old man who lives with his wife and their two children. Ghassan has been operating a photography shop for over fifteen years. He does professional pictures for individuals or events. He is an active and working man, and he does his best to improve his financial situation. In order to provide the best for his family, he works early in the morning until late in the evening, and he tries his best not to miss an occasion for photography. 

Today, for the first time, he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tapes, a digital camera, and more. 

His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he did not have many clients because he was not known by the public, but he knew how to enlarge his networking.

loans.use: To purchase tapes, a digital camera, and more.

loans.name: Kasanje Twegatte, Lugazi Group

texts.en:
In the picture, the lady squatting on the left is Immaculate M.. 48-year-old Immaculate admits it is hard for her to get out of step when she is doing her survival, trivial round, foodstuffs-selling business. It is a fledgling, four-year-old business in Kassejja Mbiko, Lugazi.

Immaculate’s good customer relationship skills have meant she has, over time, gotten into her customers’ good graces. As such, she has established for herself a niche, selling vegetables and fruit, including bananas. Her customers have mostly been village and town-traveling folk.

The 150,000 shillings Immaculate makes monthly is not enough of a safe-bet situation, according to her, as only three out of her eight children, go to school. With this loan, Immaculate is optimistic she will add to her operational business capital.

Immaculate wants to construct rental houses in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Lucy Wairimu

texts.en: Lucy is fifty years old and married with four children. She lives in Kasarani, a Nairobi suburb. Lucy operates a retail shop for selling spare motorcycle parts at Nyamakima bus terminus in Nairobi town center. She has done this for the last year. With this loan, she plans to buy stock of motorcycle spare parts to sell in her retail shop. Her customers are mainly motorcyclists at Nyamakima bus terminus.She has never borrowed from another financial institution. In the future, she hopes to develop a well-stocked shop to supply other small-scale dealers in spare parts.

loans.use: To increase her stock of spare parts for motorcycles

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr: Cette  dame  a installé depuis 2003 son propre restaurant dans lequel elle ne sert à ses clients que de  la  nourriture togolaise,  pour pouvoir bien gérer son commerce, elle a impliquée 4 personnes de sa famille dans la gestion de son commerce, sa clientèle se compose de toute personne. Elle voudrait compléter ses économies afin de se réapprovisionner avec les matières nécessaires à   son activité de restauration,  elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 6 sacs de riz, 4 bidons d’huile, 10 cartons de spaghettis et 5 sacs de maïs. Elle est divorcée de son mari et a 3 personnes à charges, c’est avec le revenu de son commerce qu’elle subvient à ses propres charges et à celle de ses enfants
texts.en:
Since 2003, this woman started her own restaurant where she sells only Togolese cuisine. In order to manage her business well, she hired four people from her family as management for her business. Her clients are made up of all kinds of people. She would like to save up her money in order to restock with the necessary supplies for her restaurant. She is asking for a loan from WAGES to purchase six sacks of rice, four barrels of oil, ten cartons of spaghetti, and five bags of maize. She is divorced from her husband and takes care of three people. With the revenue from her business, she supports herself and her children.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products

loans.name: Djata

texts.fr:
Djata K. a 62 ans, mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Elle vit chez son époux avec leurs enfants dans une famille monogame à Kaboïla II, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mené  plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle décida de faire  de la  restauration depuis maintenant plus de vingt ans. Elle appris cette activité auprès de sa mère qui faisait de la restauration lors des cérémonies  publiques.  
L’insuffisance des ressources propres suffisantes pour bien mener cette activité constitue la justification de ses demandes de prêt au niveau de Soro Yiriwaso afin de mieux satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter. 
Avec ses six  ans de collaboration, elle a obtenu plusieurs prêts solidaires dans une association des femmes de son quartier et est à son huitième prêt individuel. Tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.  
Avec ce  nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter, 8 sacs de riz, 4 sacs de mil et quelques condiments alimentaires pour les sauces, à Sikasso ville. 
Elle dispose  d’un restaurant au nouveau marché de Médine Sikasso avec une clientèle constituée pour la plupart  de vendeuses, de routiers et  de passagers. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec  un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, elle compte contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Djata K. is 62 years old, married and the mother of eight children. She lives with her husband and children in a monogamous family in Kaboïla II, a modest district in the town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). After having tried several business activities without success, she has decided to go into the restaurant business, and has been doing this for over twenty years now. She has learned this activity from her mother who used to cater food for public ceremonies. Lacking her own funds to run this business properly, she is seeking a loan from Soro Yiriwaso, with the goal of better satisfying the ever growing demand of her customers. During the six years of collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso, she has received several joint loans as part of a local women’s association and is now on her eighth individual loan. All previous loans have been duly reimbursed. With this new loan, she plans to purchase in Sikasso eight bags of rice, four bags of millet, and some food condiments for making sauces. She has an eatery at the new market of Médine Sikasso, and her clients are mainly market vendors, long-distance drivers and passengers. She anticipates achieving a monthly income of 100,000 West African francs. With the obtained income, she plans to contribute to the family budget, pay off the interest on her loan and reinvest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing food for an eatery

loans.name: Safaa

texts.en:
Safaa is a thirty-three-year-old married woman and mother of three children. In 2008, she opened a grocery store in her town. She decided to open her shop because she saw a need for such services in the region. The additional income she earns from the shop supplements her family’s other earnings, which altogether pay for their family's expenses. She offers food products, dairy products, breads, cereals, drinks, canned food, bread, candies, and more products to her clients. 
Today, Safaa is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise to stock her shop in the hopes that this will increase her sales and, therefore, her income.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to stock her shop.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian is thirty years old and married with two children. She lives in Kariobangi. Lilian operates in an urban location where most of the customers are middle-income earners. She has done this for the last six years. With this loan, she plans to add stock to her business. She has never borrowed from any other financial institutions. In the future, she hopes to expand her business into a wholesale business.

loans.use: Lilian wants the loan to add stock to her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Emglish

texts.en:
Emglish C. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions and cooking oil at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock fish to sell. Emglish is 31 years old and married. Her husband is a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a rental house. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock fish to sell

loans.name: Idrissou

texts.fr: Ce monsieur exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la boucherie, il va acheter les viandes de mouton et de bœuf dans une ferme à Adetikopé qui est un village à 20 Km de Lomé, pour y aller il se sert d’une moto, cette moto de travail est en panne et vieille, il voudrait le changer.il sollicite alors un crédit pour l’achat d’une moto afin de faciliter les déplacements dans l’exercice de son commerce.
texts.en:
This gentleman works as a butcher to generate income. To buy mutton and beef, he goes to a farm in Adetikopé, which is a village located twenty kilometers from Lomé. He uses a motorcycle to get there, but this work motorcycle is old and not running, and he would like get another. Thus he is seeking a loan for the purchase of a motorcycle in order to facilitate his business trips.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of motorcycle

loans.name: David Maina

texts.en: David, age 22, is single and lives in the Gitiha area, a Nairobi suburb. David farms in a cold and wet highland in central Kenya and Githurai town. He sells the produce in Githurai market. Githurai is a densely populated area with average income earners. David has been in this business for the last three years. With this loan, he intends to buy seedlings for kale and spinach as well as manure and fertilizer for farming. He has never borrowed from other financial institutions. In the future, he hopes to develop his farming business and start other businesses like selling T-shirts in the nearby markets.

loans.use: To buy seedlings for kale and spinach as well as manure and fertilizer for farming

loans.name: Nouhoum

texts.fr:
Âgé de 40 ans, Monsieur Nouhoum T. est marié et père de 2 enfants. Il réside dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Hamdallaye, Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Nouhoum T. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initié à une activité génératrice de revenus en l'occurrence la charge de batteries auto et téléphoniques et la vente nouvelles batteries depuis plus de trois ans.
Il dispose d’un atelier  pour la charge dans le quartier  Lafiabougou, il est beaucoup  sollicité  dans ce quartier car tout le monde n’ y a pas accès à l'électricité. En plus de  la charge de batteries, il mène aussi l’activité de vente ciment en provenance de Lomé ( république du Togo).
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux ans. Il est  à son deuxième prêt individuel pour acheter, 1 nouvel appareil  pour  la charge de batteries.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Forty years old, Mr. Nouhoum T. is married and the father of two children. He lives in a large, traditional extended family in Hamdallaye, Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After working many jobs without success, three years ago Mr. T. began a business charging car and telephone batteries and selling new batteries. He has a workshop for charging in the Lafiabougou neighborhood. He's very much in demand in this area because not everyone has access to electricity. In addition to charging batteries, he also sells cement from Lomé (Republic of Togo). Wanting to satisfy his ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yirwaso two years ago. He is seeking his second individual loan in order to buy a new battery charger. With this loan he plans to make a monthly profit of 150,000 FCFA, which will mainly be used to bolster his working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay interest on the loan, with the remainder to be invested in his business.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of battery charger

loans.name: Vidal

texts.es:
El Sr. Vidal P. tiene 38 años de edad, esta casado con la Sra. Teresa hace 15 años, tienen 4 hijos, viven en una Villa llamado Moreira de la ciudad de Coronel Oviedo hace mas de cinco años. 
Don Vidal comenzó siendo ayudante de albañil desde pequeño, aprendió el oficio siendo independiente hace 16 años,  ahora es Oficial de Obras trabajando también con firmas constructoras.
Su trabajo es el sustento de su familia a quien educa con los valores de Honestidad, responsabilidad, sencillez y solidaridad.
Comenta que es difícil conseguir apoyo crediticio para su oficio por lo agradece a Fundación Paraguaya por ofrecerle la oportunidad y de esta manera poder mejorar el nivel de su trabajo, ya que con el crédito comprara herramientas (carretilla y mezcladora)para su grupo de trabajo en un asentamiento en construcción de varias viviendas a su cargo.
texts.en:
Vidal P. is 38 years old. He has been married to Teresa for fifteen years. They have four children. They have lived in a town named Moreira in Coronel Oviedo for more than five years. Mr. Vidal has been a builder's assistant since he was young. He began working independently sixteen years ago. He also now works as a foreman for construction firms. Vidal's work supports his family, who he teaches the values of honesty, responsibility, simplicity, and solidarity. He says it is difficult to get credit support for his business, which is why he is grateful to Paraguaya Foundation for giving him this opportunity to be able to improve the level of his work. With this loan, he will be able to buy tools (a wheelbarrow and a mixer) for his team working at a settlement under construction, where they are responsible for building multiple homes.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying tools (wheelbarrow and mixer)

loans.name: Hanna

texts.en:
Hanna is married and blessed with three children who are in school. She runs a business selling African attire and curios to earn a living. She has been in this business since the year of 1997. Her customers are both local people and tourists. She also rears dairy cattle to earn extra income. 
 
Hanna is an active member of a Faulu Kenya group who meet on a weekly basis to save their money. She has really benefited from the group: with the loans that the group guaranteed for her, she has been able to pay school fees for her children, built her family a house, and bought dairy cattle. Her wish is to see her children go through college and be professionals. She has requested a loan of 55,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of African attire and curios to sell.

loans.use: To add stock of African attire and curios for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Djénèbou

texts.fr:
Djénèbou K. N.est une veuve de 37 ans et mère de cinq enfants  qui vit avec ses enfants chez son défunt époux à Wayerma I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso.
Djénèbou K. N.mène une activité d’achat et de vente   des draps de lits,  de pagnes wax et  de bois de chauffe depuis plus de quatre ans. 
Elle jouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes, mais ses ressources ne peuvent pas lui permettre de les satisfaire. 
Après plusieurs prêts solidaires, et deux prêts individuels, elle est à son troisième individuel avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter, 20 paquets de draps de lits, 5 complets de tissus brodés et 5 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe, respectivement à Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso) et dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso.  
  Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 90.000 FCFA qui sera utiliser pour  contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Djénèbou K. N.is a 37-year-old widow and the mother of five children. She lives with her children in her deceased spouse's home in Wayerma I, one of the working-class districts of the city of Sikasso. For four years Djénèbou K. N.has been running a business buying and selling bed linens, pagnes wax (colorful West African cloth), and firewood. She has a good reputation in the business and receives many orders, but her resources do not permit her to fill them. After several group loans and two individual loans, she is seeking her third individual loan with Soro Yiriwaso in order to buy twenty sets of bed linens, five suits of embroidered cloth, and 5 cartloads of firewood, in Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso) and in areas surrounding the city of Sikasso. With this loan, she plans to make a monthly profit of 90,000 FCA, which will be used to contribute to family expenses and to pay interest on her loan, with the remainder to be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Ametossina

texts.fr: Cette femme s’est lancé dans un commerce d'un genre particulier qui est le commerce en détail de gravier qu'elle stocke dans des bassines, elle s’approvisionne au port autonome de Lomé par convoyage de camions. elle a reçu des commandes de ses clients, pour les satisfaire, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour le convoyage de 4 camions de graviers. Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
Ametossina A. started a very special business, namely retailing gravel. She stores the gravel in large basins. She gets her supplies at the Autonomous Port of Lomé and conveys them by truck. She secured a few orders from customers; to carry them out, she came to WAGES and applied for a loan to convey four trucks of gravel. Ametossina is married and the mother of one child.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy gravel

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah T. is currently in the business of selling various foodstuffs at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice, beans, cassava flour, etc., to cook and sell in the restaurant.  Sarah is a 30-year-old married woman, and her husband is a builder. She has four children who go to school.  With the extra profits that she could earn from her loan, she hopes to extend the floor of her restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Increase inventory of rice, beans, cassava flour etc., for her restaurant

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is married with children and all her children are going to school. She stays in Bwaise Lufula Zone, Kawempe Division, Kampala District. Grace takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a three roomed house where she stays with additional family members. Grace has opeartes a school canteen and also works as a clerk at the school. She has been in this business for a short period  and works seven days a week. Grace iniataily  had a retail shop but changed her enterprise to a canteen at a nearby school. The family has access to electricity and piped water. She wants to use this loan to buy more bread, cakes, donuts, mineral water and other eatables for the canteen. Grace’s monthly expenses include school fees and food. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and own another plot of land.

loans.use: To buy bread (buns), cakes, donuts, mineral water and juices for the canteen

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell.

loans.name: Yangi

texts.en:
Yangi M. is currently in the business of selling dried fish, tomatoes, onions and groundnut phase and is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes and cooking oil to sell. Yangi is 47 years old and is widowed.   She has seven children, and none of them go to school.  With the extra profits that she could earn from her loan, she dreams of building her own restaurant.


BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock irish potatoes and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is a 25 year old single lady who sells spare parts of automobiles in Nairobi. She has been running this business for the last two years, and she says that her business environment is conducive. She maintains that since the time she joined Faulu, her business has grown due to training and availability of credit. She is a member of C. Market self help group that has guaranteed her to get a loan of Kes. 50,000 to add stock of spare parts for automobiles. She describes herself as industrious and as being focused.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for automobiles

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se encuentra integrada por 19 mujeres que estan muy satisfechas con el trabajo que realizan para salir adelante con sus familias de la mejor manera posible.
Cada una realiza una actividad de acuerdo a la facilidad con cuenta y el gusto de cada una.  
La Sra. Lourdes V. se dedica a la distribución de mercaderías de uso en el hogar principalmente, entre las cuales se pueden mencionar: utencilios de cocina, mercería, bazar, artículos de limpieza, lencería, herramientas de mano, costurería.
Teniendo en cuenta la demanda y el empeño y dedicación a su trabajo, desea incrementar sus ingresos económicos, auemntando el estock de mercaderías que posee, adecuándose a lo más solicitado por la clientela como utencilios de cocina, merceria, bazar y otros.
texts.en:
This group is made up of nineteen women, who are very happy with the work they do to help their families get ahead in life the best way possible. Each woman works in accordance with her own abilities and likes. Mrs. Lourdes V. sells items for household use: kitchen utensils, hardware supplies, cleaning supplies, linens, hand tools, and sewing supplies. Considering consumer demand and the effort and dedication she puts into her work, Lourdes wants to increase her income by growing her stock of merchandise, adapting it to those products most-requested by her customers like kitchen utensils, hardware supplies, and others.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying merchandise to sell: kitchen utensils, hardware supplies, cleaning supplies, etc.

loans.name: Pita

texts.en:
Pita S. is currently in the business of importing and selling rolls of bedsheets from Khartoum, and is requesting a loan to import more rolls of bedsheets to sell.  Pita is a 45-year-old married woman, and her husband is the director of labour office. She has seven children who go to school. With the extra profits that she could earn from her loan, she hopes to build a departmental store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Import more rolls of bedsheets  to sell

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a 26-year-old single man. He sells African attires and curios in his shop to earn a living. He has been running the business for four years now. He has many customers, including the local people as well as tourists. He also does dairy farming to earn extra income.  He is a young member of a group in Faulu Kenya called City Mark Youth where he saves his money on a weekly basis. The group guarantees members loans. Peter is determined to grow his business, now that he can access loans, and this is his first loan.  He hopes to grow his business into a wholesale and expand his market share to other countries. He has requested a loan of kes 50,000 from Faulu Kenya to add stock of African attire and curios for sale.

loans.use: To add stock of African attire and curios for sale

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is 52 years old and married with three children who are in school.  She runs a boutique to earn a living. She has been in the business for nine years and has one employee.   She saves her money with her group in Faulu Kenya called Dafulos on a weekly basis, which enables her to borrow loans because the group guarantees. She had previously taken out two loans from Faulu Kenya which she used to expand her business, and she successfully repaid.  She hopes that she will have saved enough money so that she can have a good retirement after work in the future. Her wish is to see her children through the university.   She has requested a loan of 50,000 KES from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Ferida

texts.en:
Ferida M. is currently in the business of selling groundnuts and simsim (sesame seeds) from her home and is requesting a loan to stock maize flour to sell.  Ferida is 30 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock maize flour to sell

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formo a través de la Sra. Teofila Franco, quien se había acercado hasta la Oficina de la Fundación Paraguaya para interiorizarce mas del  Programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, la misma invito a sus amigas y compañeras del Barrio y decidieron sumarse al trabajo grupal para salir adelante y así mejorar su estilo de vida, son 16 mujeres trabajadoras y humildes que deben ganarse el sustento todos los dias. 
La Señora Francisca M. se dedica a la venta de ropas de segunda mano, provenientes del exterior del país, pretende incrementar sus ingresos aprovechando el cambio de temporada otoño-invierno, invirtiendo en la compra al por mayor de ropas como: remeras mangas largas, camperas, pantalones, abrigos en gral.que estan siendo sumamente demandadas por la gran clientela que acude a ella.
texts.en:
This group was formed by Mrs. Teofila Franco, who approached the Foundation Paraguaya office to familiarize herself with their program working with groups of entrepreneurial women. She invited her friends and women from the neighborhood to join her. They decided to join together to work to get ahead and improve their quality of life. They are sixteen hard-working and humble women who earn their sustenance daily. Mrs. Francisca M. sells second-hand clothes that come from outside the country. She plans to increase her income by taking advantage of the change in seasons from fall to winter and investing in the wholesale purchase of clothes like long-sleeved shirts, jackets, pants, and coats, which are in high demand among her many customers.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying seasonal clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Khamisa

texts.en:
Khamisa A. is currently in the business of selling dried fish and charcoal from her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Khamisa is 28 years old and is married to an electrician. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by building a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is a 37-year-old businessman who operates a metal fabrication business. He has been running this business for ten years and refers to his business environment as busy. He is married and the father of five who range from one to ten years of age. He was a mechanic previously. 

Michael has requested a loan of 25,000 KES to add to his stock of metal pipes and sheets. He describes himself as hardworking and enterprising.

loans.use: To buy metal pipes and sheets

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more food to sell.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 37 years old and married with two children who go to school. He runs a shop where he sells general merchandise such as rice, sugar, plastics, cooking fat and cereals to earn a living. He has been in the business for seven years and has many customers due to his good customer care skills. He talks to his customers well and gives credit to his best customers which keeps them returning.

He saves his money with his group in Faulu Kenya called Mwimuto Success which enables him to access loans because the group guarantees.  He hopes to grow his business and open branches in the future. He has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Faulu Kenya to add to his stock of flour, rice and soft drinks.

loans.use: To buy more flour, rice and soft drinks to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nsasa Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Leocadia is 35 years old and is married with four school-going children. She runs a five-year-old dairy business selling milk in Nsasa, Mukono. In a week, this cheerfully approachable woman reckons she makes 90,000 shillings.

The major challenge Leocadia has faced since she began has been the low volume of milk supplies she gets from her suppliers, most of them small-scale cattle keepers. With this loan, she wants to buy her own thoroughbred cow that will give her enough milk so that she does not run out of supplies.

loans.use: To purchase a thoroughbred cow of her own

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more palm kernel to sell.

loans.name: Salan

texts.en:
Salan C. is currently in the business of baking and selling local Sudanese bread and is requesting a loan to stock more baking materials like cooking oil, baking flour etc. for more production.  Salan is 32 years old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has two children and her children go to school.  If she is able to make extra profits as a result her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant

loans.use: Buy more baking materials like cooking oil and baking flour.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married with children and all her go school. Her husband is porter ( builder) Nabulagala. Rose rents a ???? 

Rose is married with children and all her ??? go to school. Her husband is a porter (builder) in Nabulagala. Rose rents a house where the family resides and also takes care of additional family members. Besides the grocery shop, Rose also sells charcoal and sells to all categories of people at both retail and wholesale. She has owned these businesses for a long time. Rose doesn’t pay rent for these businesses because she works from her home. Rose works six days. Her business challenges include transportation and thieves. She wants to use this loan partly to boost her business of charcoal and partly for her grocery, She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start selling at wholesale only. Rose joined MCDT because it was working with women who are in groups of five.

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin is a 44-year-old married father of nine. Four of the nine children are in school. He operates a tailoring business in Nairobi – a business he has been running for twelve years. 

Benjamin is a member of the Sunshine Self-Help Group in Faulu whose members guarantee each other to get loans. He is requesting a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to add stock of fabric to his business. He describes his business environment as favourable and hopes to open a workshop. He also desires to educate all his children to university level and describes himself as honest.

loans.use: To add stock of fabric

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more palm kennel to sell.

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en:
Douglas is 36 years old and married with three children who are in school. He runs a taxi business to earn a living. He has been in the business for six years now. He says that he has a good customer base due to his experience and good customer care skills. He describes himself as an ambitious and hardworking man. 

Douglas saves his money on a weekly basis with a group in Faulu Kenya called C. Market. The group enables him to access loans with group guarantees. He has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to paint his car so that he can attract more customers. He hopes to grow his business and buy more vehicles in the future.

loans.use: To paint his vehicle

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Juliana is 41 years old and married. Her husband is a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school.

loans.name: Espiritu Emprendedor Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formo  se ecuentra integrada por 16 mujeres trabajadoras y emprendedoras con muchos deseos de trabajar y así mejorar su estilo de vida.
Ellas  son independientes en sus labores como vendedoras de ropas, venta de comidas, tienen almacén, copetín, tienen huertas y comercializan sus propios productos. Venden articulos de limpieza, mercería, venden carbon, mandioca, Venta de Producto Avón,etc. 
La Sra. Cristina F. se dedica a la venta de productos de uso personal y de la vivienda, ya sean cosméticos, utencilios de cocina, perfumes, útiles escolares, pequeñas herramientas de mano etc.
Todo esto actuando de representante de una empresa comercial distribuidora.
Ella tiene una gran clientela ya formada y teniendo en cuenta la demanda de productos desea incrementar sus ingresos ampliando el estock de los productos que posee para su comercialización.
texts.en:
This group is made up of 16 hard-working and enterprising women. They are eager to work and improve their quality of life. They are independently occupied and work selling clothing, food and beverages or running stores, working market gardens and promoting their own products. They sell cleaning supplies, hardware, coal, cassava plants, Avon products etc. Mrs. Cristina F. sells personal products such as cosmetics, kitchen gadgets, perfumes, school supplies, small hand tools etc. from her home. She works as a representative for a commercial distributing business. She has already secured a large customer base and has a great demand for her products. She would like to grow her earnings by increasing the stock of products that she has to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy nail polish, nail polish remover, nail clippers, cotton, nail files, pumice stones, Avon products etc.

loans.name: Deri

texts.en:
Deri R. is currently in the business of selling bread, ice cream, mangoes, etc.,  and is requesting a loan to stock onions and tomatoes to sell.  Deri is a 19-year-old single woman.  She has children who go to school.  With the extra profits that she could earn from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a restaurant and a house for rent.
